title: Unlocking Growth in Renewable Energy and Green Investment
excerpt: As the world accelerates towards a low-carbon future, Papua New Guinea is uniquely positioned to benefit from the global transition to renewable energy and sustainable business practices. With vast potential in hydropower, solar, biomass, and wind, PNG offers green investment opportunities that can deliver both financial returns and environmental impact.
content:
Introduction


As the world accelerates towards a low-carbon future, Papua New Guinea is uniquely positioned to benefit from the global transition to renewable energy and sustainable business practices. With vast potential in hydropower, solar, biomass, and wind, PNG offers green investment opportunities that can deliver both financial returns and environmental impact.



Renewable Energy Potential


Hydropower remains PNG’s most significant renewable energy source, given the country’s mountainous terrain and abundant rainfall. Solar energy, meanwhile, is emerging as an increasingly viable option for rural electrification, providing reliable solutions to off-grid communities. Biomass, particularly from PNG’s agricultural sector, presents additional avenues for sustainable energy production.



Alignment with Global Trends


Global investors are seeking markets that offer both profitability and sustainability. PNG’s commitments under the Paris Agreement and its national energy transition strategy provide assurance that renewable energy development is not only encouraged but actively supported at the policy level.



Beyond Energy – Green Finance and Carbon Markets


Investors can also explore PNG’s role in carbon markets, forestry conservation, and climate-smart agriculture. These areas are linked to global trends in environmental, social, and governance (ESG) investing, making PNG an attractive partner for sustainable finance.



Key Points


  • Hydropower and solar energy provide large-scale and rural solutions.

  • PNG’s climate commitments strengthen the case for renewable investment.

  • Carbon finance and green projects align with ESG investor priorities.
author: Unknown

title: Digital Transformation – The New Frontier for Investment in PNG
excerpt: While natural resources remain vital to PNG’s economy, the digital economy is rapidly emerging as the next major growth frontier. Investment in ICT infrastructure, digital services, and e-commerce is reshaping the business landscape and creating unprecedented opportunities for both local and international investors.
content:
Introduction


While natural resources remain vital to PNG’s economy, the digital economy is rapidly emerging as the next major growth frontier. Investment in ICT infrastructure, digital services, and e-commerce is reshaping the business landscape and creating unprecedented opportunities for both local and international investors.



ICT and Connectivity Growth


Ongoing investments in undersea cables and mobile networks are improving connectivity across the country. As internet penetration grows, so too does demand for online services, digital platforms, and fintech solutions that can bridge the gap between consumers and businesses.



Opportunities in E-Governance and Business Solutions


The PNG Government is prioritising digitalisation across public services, from e-government platforms to digital registries. Investors in software development, cybersecurity, and cloud solutions can support this transformation while accessing a growing market of institutional clients.



E-Commerce and Fintech


With a young and increasingly tech-savvy population, PNG is seeing rapid adoption of digital payments and e-commerce. Start-ups and investors focusing on digital financial services, logistics solutions, and online marketplaces are well placed to benefit from this momentum.



Key Points


  • ICT infrastructure development is enabling rapid growth of the digital economy.

  • E-governance and digital business solutions are opening new B2B markets.

  • E-commerce and fintech are expanding consumer access and creating high-return opportunities.
author: Unknown

title: Why Papua New Guinea is Emerging as the Pacific’s Investment Hub
excerpt: Papua New Guinea (PNG) is increasingly recognised as a strategic destination for investment within the Asia-Pacific region. With abundant natural resources, a young workforce, and its proximity to growing Asian markets, PNG offers investors a unique blend of opportunities across traditional and emerging sectors.
content:
Introduction


Papua New Guinea (PNG) is increasingly recognised as a strategic destination for investment within the Asia-Pacific region. With abundant natural resources, a young workforce, and its proximity to growing Asian markets, PNG offers investors a unique blend of opportunities across traditional and emerging sectors.



Market Potential


PNG is endowed with rich natural resources — from gold, copper, and natural gas to fertile agricultural land and vast forestry reserves. These resources form the backbone of the country’s economy, yet remain underdeveloped in many areas, leaving significant space for both domestic and foreign investment.


At the same time, sectors such as digital services, tourism, and renewable energy are rapidly expanding, driven by both global demand and local policy reforms.



Strategic Location


Located at the crossroads of Asia and the Pacific, PNG provides investors with a natural gateway to Australia, Southeast Asia, and beyond. Enhanced connectivity through major ports and aviation hubs strengthens its position as a regional trade partner.



Business Climate and Reforms


The Investment Promotion Authority has spearheaded reforms aimed at improving ease of doing business, streamlining company registration, and facilitating investor services. These developments align PNG with global best practices, ensuring that investors can operate in a predictable and transparent environment.



Key Points


  • PNG’s natural resources offer enduring opportunities for long-term investment.

  • Strategic geographic positioning enhances global trade connectivity.

  • Reforms in governance and business registration are fostering a more investor-friendly climate.
author: IPA

title: Eywa Systems Supports EU-FCCB Digital Transformation in Papua New Guinea
excerpt: Eywa Systems has announced its active support for the European Union–Forestry, Climate Change and Biodiversity Programme (EU-FCCB) in Papua New Guinea (PNG), delivering cutting-edge digital solutions to accelerate the country’s environmental governance and sustainable development agenda.
content:
Copenhagen, Denmark — 10-09-2025

 

Eywa Systems has announced its active support for the European Union–Forestry, Climate Change and Biodiversity Programme (EU-FCCB) in Papua New Guinea (PNG), delivering cutting-edge digital solutions to accelerate the country’s environmental governance and sustainable development agenda.

 

The EU-FCCB programme, implemented by Expertise France in partnership with PNG’s government institutions, focuses on strengthening climate action, forest conservation, and biodiversity management. Eywa Systems has been engaged to design and implement advanced digital platforms that enable transparent reporting, improved collaboration, and long-term sustainability of PNG’s climate and forest monitoring frameworks.

 

Driving Digital Transformation in Climate Governance

 

As part of the engagement, Eywa Systems is leading the development and integration of several mission-critical solutions, including:

  • The National Carbon Registry (NCR): A secure, modern platform to register and track carbon projects, aligned with UNFCCC Article 6 requirements and global carbon market standards.
  • Safeguards Information Systems (SIS): A comprehensive tool to monitor and report on social and environmental safeguards under the REDD+ framework.
  • Agency Websites and Digital Infrastructure: Modernisation of websites and ICT systems across key FCCB partner agencies, including the Climate Change and Development Authority (CCDA), the Papua New Guinea Forest Authority (PNGFA), the Department of Lands and Physical Planning (DLPP), and the Conservation and Environment Protection Authority (CEPA).

 

Through these initiatives, Eywa Systems is enabling PNG to improve the integrity of its data, ensure compliance with international climate finance mechanisms, and strengthen transparency in managing natural resources.

 

Building Capacity and Resilience

 

In addition to system development, Eywa Systems is providing capacity building and knowledge transfer to ensure sustainability. Training workshops on ICT governance, cybersecurity, and data management are equipping local teams with the skills needed to operate and maintain the new platforms.

 

“Digital transformation is a cornerstone of effective climate action,” said Benjamin Irani, Principal Solutions Engineer at Eywa Systems. “By combining cutting-edge technology with local ownership, we are helping PNG build robust systems that not only meet today’s reporting requirements but also support long-term resilience and sustainable development.”

 

A Strategic Partnership

 

Eywa Systems’ support to the EU-FCCB programme underscores its long-standing expertise in delivering digital transformation for climate action, combining advanced ICT solutions with international development priorities.

 

The partnership reflects Eywa’s commitment to supporting countries like Papua New Guinea in bridging technology with sustainability—empowering governments to meet international obligations while ensuring benefits for local communities and ecosystems.


About Eywa Systems

Eywa Systems is a Denmark-based digital transformation company specialising in software engineering, cloud computing, cybersecurity, and AI solutions. With a track record of supporting international organisations, government agencies, and NGOs, Eywa Systems empowers institutions to modernise operations, strengthen governance, and achieve sustainable growth.

 

Press Contact

Eywa Systems

Email: info@eywasystems.com

Phone: +45 53 72 72 44

Website: www.eywasystems.com
author: matin

title: Hon. Peter Namea Isoaimo, MP, new Minister for Energy
content:
The National Energy Authority (NEA) proudly announces the appointment of Hon. Peter Namea Isoaimo, MP, as Papua New Guinea’s new Minister for Energy. The Member for Kairuku was officially sworn in at Government House this afternoon, following a minor Cabinet reshuffle.

Minister Isoaimo, a senior member of the National Alliance Party, brings with him over a decade of leadership and governance experience in Parliament. First elected in 2014, he has served with distinction in several key roles, including Vice Minister for Works and Highways and Vice Minister for Treasury, and has contributed extensively to parliamentary committees on economic affairs, public works, law and order, and environmental management. His career reflects a long-standing commitment to public service and a dedication to improving the lives of Papua New Guineans through sound leadership and policy.

As Minister for Energy, Hon. Peter Isoaimo assumes leadership of the sector at a pivotal time, when energy development is central to economic growth and national sustainability. He will oversee major initiatives in LNG, renewable energy, and rural electrification, working in close partnership with the NEA to deliver the Government’s vision of reliable, affordable, and sustainable energy for all. The NEA looks forward to working under his leadership to advance transformative projects that will drive inclusive development, empower communities, and secure Papua New Guinea’s long-term energy future.

The NEA also extends its sincere appreciation to the former Minister for Energy, Hon. Thomas Opa, MP, who has taken on a new ministerial role as Minister for Finance. We acknowledge his valuable contributions during his tenure, from serving as Vice Minister for Petroleum and Energy to leading as Minister for Energy. His leadership was instrumental in advancing NEA’s mission, and we look forward to his continued support for Papua New Guinea’s energy agenda as a senior member of the Marape-Rosso Government.
author: NEA

title: Papua New Guinea National Energy Access Transformation Project
content:
Papua New Guinea National Energy Access Transformation Project

The Papua New Guinea National Energy Access Transformation Project (NEAT or the ‘Project’) will be financed by the World Bank and implemented by the National Energy Authority (NEA) and PNG Power Limited (PPL). The project will support the GoPNG in achieving its energy access target through investments in on-grid electrification, sustainable renewable energy mini-grids, private sector-led off-grid market promotion, and institutional development.

The Project consists of four components:

  • Component 1: Rehabilitation, resiliency enhancement of PPL infrastructure, and on-grid electrification – This component will improve the capacity and reliability of electricity services and increase household (HH) connections for electrification and, through the PPP scheme, facilitate private sector involvement. This component has three subcomponents: i) Subcomponent 1.1: Rehabilitation and modernization of distribution networks; ii) Subcomponent 1.2: Grid densification and expansion for household connections; and iii) Subcomponent 1.3: Pilot Public Private Partnership in PPL mini-grid clean energy modernization which includes the provision of Viability Gap Financing (VGF) to a private company that will build, operate, own, and transfer (BOOT) mini-grid, through PPL.

  • Component 2: Renewable energy micro-grids and rural energy market development – This component aims to expand energy access in remote communities that are not served by PPL. Subcomponent 2.1: Micro-grid systems aims to provide investment grants through NEA to private service providers to install, operate, and maintain RE-based micro-grid systems in rural areas. Subcomponent 2.2: Solar-home systems (SHSs) and products aims to increase the uptake of quality-verified SHSs and solar products in rural areas, through establishing a funding mechanism to provide catalytic grants and result-based financing (RBF) grants to eligible solar companies to extend their supply chains, develop markets, and scale-up the sales of certified off-grid solar energy kits.

  • Component 3: Energy sector institutional development. This component aims to strengthen PPL and NEA’s capabilities to plan, survey, design, coordinate, and implement the NEROP to achieve the GoPNG’s national energy access targets and to support the two entities in conducting strategic studies. Subcomponent 3.1. ‘NEA institutional development’ will provide technical assistance for key studies for Project implementation, sector policy development, and related capacity building programs to be conducted by NEA.  Subcomponent 3.2. ‘PPL institutional development’ will provide technical assistance for site identification and pre-feasibility studies for small hydropower and other variable RE, and support for technical capacity development of PPL.

  • Component 4: Project management – This component aims to support the respective project management by NEA and PPL.

The project’s Environmental and Social Framework (ESMF) will serve as the Project’s umbrella for environmental and social management. This ESMF aims to guide NEA and PPL on the environmental and social screening of the Project activities and subsequent environmental and social assessment and management of these activities during project preparation, design, and implementation. Other key E&S instruments include the Environmental and Social Commitment Plan (ESCP); Stakeholder Engagement Plan (SEP); Land Access and Resettlement Framework (LARF); Labour Management Procedure (LMP) – refer to ESMF Annex; and Indigenous Peoples’ Policy Framework (IPPF) – refer ESMF Annex.
author: NEA
